title: Understanding Tenses in Grammar
narration: Welcome to this comprehensive guide on understanding tenses in grammar

title: What is Tense?
content:
Tense indicates the time of an action or event.
It helps us understand **when** something happens.
Tenses can be past, present, or future.
image_desc: Clock showing different times. Type: illustration
narration: Tense in grammar refers to the time of an action or event. It's a crucial element that helps us understand when something is happening whether it's in the past present or future.

title: Three Main Types of Tenses
content:
**Present Tense**
Simple Present: She writes a blog.
Present Continuous: She is writing a blog.
Present Perfect: She has written a blog.
Present Perfect Continuous: She has been writing a blog for two hours.
**Past Tense**
Simple Past: She wrote a blog.
Past Continuous: She was writing a blog.
Past Perfect: She had written a blog before lunch.
Past Perfect Continuous: She had been writing a blog for two hours before lunch.
narration: There are three main types of tenses present past and future. Each of these tenses has four subcategories that provide even more specific information about the timing of an action.

title: Future Tense
content:
Simple Future: She will write a blog.
Future Continuous: She will be writing a blog.
Future Perfect: She will have written a blog by tomorrow.
Future Perfect Continuous: She will have been writing a blog for two hours by noon.
image_desc: Calendar showing future dates. Type: illustration
narration: Finally let's consider the future tense which describes actions that will happen. The future tense also has four subcategories simple future future continuous future perfect and future perfect continuous.
